title: Caesium or Cesium - Periodic Table of Videos

multiple-choice.question: What is the surprising use of caesium?

options.label: A
options.text: It is used to measure the speed of light.

options.label: B
options.text: It is used to measure the temperature of objects.

options.label: C
options.text: It is used to measure the length of objects.

options.label: D
options.text: It is used to measure time.

multiple-choice.question: How do scientists define the second?

options.label: A
options.text: In terms of the length of a day.

options.label: B
options.text: In terms of the speed of light.

options.label: C
options.text: In terms of the temperature of objects.

options.label: D
options.text: In terms of the frequency of microwaves emitted by caesium.

multiple-choice.question: What is the advantage of using caesium to define the frequency of microwaves?

options.label: A
options.text: It is very small and can absorb microwaves easily.

options.label: B
options.text: It is very heavy and can absorb microwaves quickly.

options.label: C
options.text: It is very light and can absorb microwaves slowly.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a large atom that can absorb microwaves and define the frequency very accurately.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of storing caesium under oil?

options.label: A
options.text: To prevent it from reacting with air.

multiple-choice.question: What is the reason for punching a hole in the plastic boat containing caesium?

options.label: C
options.text: To lift it out with a piece of string.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of using liquid nitrogen to refreeze caesium?

options.label: C
options.text: To prevent it from reacting with air.

options.label: D
options.text: To refreeze it and make it more stable, so it can be handled safely.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the reaction between caesium and water?

options.label: A
options.text: The formation of water and a caesium salt.

options.label: B
options.text: The formation of oxygen gas and a caesium salt.

options.label: C
options.text: The formation of hydrogen gas and a caesium salt.

options.label: D
options.text: The formation of carbon dioxide and a caesium salt.

multiple-choice.question: What is the reason for the violent reaction between caesium and water?

options.label: A
options.text: Because caesium is a small atom.

options.label: B
options.text: Because caesium is a heavy atom.

options.label: C
options.text: Because caesium is a light atom.

options.label: D
options.text: Because caesium is a large atom, which can easily release an electron and react violently with water.

multiple-choice.question: What is the product of the reaction between caesium and water?
What happens when hydrogen gas reacts with oxygen in the air?

options.label: A
options.text: It forms carbon dioxide and water.

options.label: B
options.text: It forms oxygen gas and water.

options.label: C
options.text: It forms hydrogen gas and water.

options.label: D
options.text: It forms water and releases heat and light, in the form of a small explosion or a big one, depending on the amount of caesium used.

multiple-choice.question: According to Mark Zuckerberg, a squirrel dying in your front yard may be more relevant to your interest right now than people dying in Africa. This idea is related to what kind of web?

options.label: D
options.text: A web based on search history

options.label: A

options.text: Facebook was looking at which links he clicked on and noticed he was clicking more on liberal friends' links, and edited them out without consulting him

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It only shows information that is tailored to the user's interests

multiple-choice.question: Mark Zuckerberg mentions that the founding mythology of the internet is that it swept away human gatekeepers and allowed us to connect together. However, but actually, what is happening?

options.label: A
options.text: The internet is replacing human gatekeepers with algorithmic ones

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The internet is not changing the role of gatekeepers

options.label: A
options.text: To only show information that is relevant to the user

options.label: B
options.text: To encode a sense of civic responsibility into the code, to be transparent, and to give users control over the information they see

options.label: C
options.text: To only show information that is tailored to the user's interests

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the number of human gatekeepers

multiple-choice.question: Mark Zuckerberg mentions that we've actually been here before as a society, in 1915, when newspapers were critical because they were acting as the filter. What was the result of this?

options.label: C
options.text: The reduction of the number of newspapers

options.label: D
options.text: The increase in the number of human gatekeepers

multiple-choice.question: According to Mark Zuckerberg, what do we need from the new gatekeepers on the web?

options.label: A
options.text: To only show information that is relevant to the user

options.label: B
options.text: To be transparent enough that we can see what the rules are that determine what gets through our filters, and to give users control over the information they see

options.label: C
options.text: To increase the number of human gatekeepers

options.label: D
options.text: To only show information that is tailored to the user's interests

multiple-choice.question: According to Mark Zuckerberg, what is the ultimate goal of the internet?

options.label: A
options.text: To leave us all isolated in a web of one

options.label: B
options.text: To connect us all together and introduce us to new ideas and new people and different perspectives

options.label: C
options.text: To only show information that is relevant to the user

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the number of human gatekeepers

title: What we can learn from galaxies far, far away - Henry Lin

multiple-choice.question: What are galaxy clusters primarily composed of?

options.label: D
options.text: Their ability to act as scaled-down versions of the universe

options.label: C
options.text: To accelerate particles of gas to great speeds

options.label: D
options.text: To act as particle accelerators at a huge scale

multiple-choice.question: What is the name given to the mysterious force driving the accelerated expansion of the universe?

options.text: To track the two biggest parts of the universe (i.e., clusters of galaxies)

options.label: C
options.text: To study the hot gas in galaxy clusters

options.label: D
options.text: To observe the effects of dark energy

options.label: B
options.text: Broadening our field of vision and stepping back

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: The little positions of every single little piece of the universe

options.label: B
options.text: The two biggest parts of the universe (i.e., clusters of galaxies)

options.label: C
options.text: The hot gas in galaxy clusters

options.label: D
options.text: The effects of dark energy on the universe

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are small and compact

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are large and contain dark matter

options.label: C
options.text: Because they act as particle accelerators at a huge scale

options.label: A
options.text: Galaxy clusters are a small part of the universe

options.label: B
options.text: Galaxy clusters are a scaled-down version of the universe

options.label: C
options.text: Galaxy clusters are the only objects in the universe

options.label: D
options.text: Galaxy clusters are not related to the universe at large scales

options.text: They are isolated systems that can be thought of as scaled-down versions of the universe

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the purpose of galaxy clusters in terms of dark energy?

options.label: C
options.text: To understand how dark energy affects the universe at the largest scales

options.label: D
options.text: To act as particle accelerators at a huge scale

options.text: Galaxy clusters are a small part of the universe's large-scale structure

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Why do we cry? The three types of tears - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason Iris cries a lot?

options.label: C
options.text: She has to cry to produce basal tears

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of the basal tears Iris produces?

options.label: C
options.text: To keep dirt and debris away

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the sulfoxides in Onion's jacket when it is removed?

options.label: B
options.text: They become a gas that stings Iris

options.label: C
options.text: They are converted into a substance with a long name: syn-Propanethial S-oxide

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between basal tears and reflex tears?

options.label: C
options.text: Basal tears are released in smaller amounts

options.label: D
options.text: Reflex tears are released in larger amounts to wash away harmful substances

multiple-choice.question: Why does Iris start crying uncontrollably when Onion takes off her jacket?

options.label: A
options.text: Because she is allergic to something

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the chemical reaction that happens when the sulfoxides are converted into syn-Propanethial S-oxide

multiple-choice.question: What is the main purpose of emotional tears?

options.label: C
options.text: To elicit sympathy or show submission

multiple-choice.question: What is the composition of the lipid layer of Iris' tears?

options.label: A
options.text: A water-based film that keeps the surface smooth

options.label: D
options.text: An oily film that keeps the surface smooth
